title: Star Wars Salt and Pepper Shakers

description.text:
To round out my "Star Wars Party Pack", here is a salt and
pepper shaker set. They are about 3" all around. The bottoms have tabs that fit
into slots in the top and the lid slides sideways to close
(see pictures). There are also files that are smaller (called SM in the name).
They are about 2" all around. The bottoms print without support. The tops need a little bit
of support in the center. Click on the "Remixed From" section to download the rest of
my party pack: Millennium Falcon Dish and Light Saber
Toothpicks. I may play with the Storm Trooper design a little more,
I'm not 100% happy with it.

author: Karen5R

description.text:
I wanted to make something to display minis at my desk.  I decided to make a simple bracket to hang different types of scenery I could paint and place the miniatures on.  
I always liked the doorway attack thing, so I used it as my test piece before I made the castle.  The cool thing with the castle, since it has to be glued together, is you can stack as many middle tower parts as you can fit on the wall.  
The displayed tower section was my prototype.  I have revised some of the files.

The assembly stl is just a total assembly of one of each part.  The bracket is center designed, so it can't really be installed incorrectly.  Hang it in the cubicle slots and then hang your terrain on the hook.  
Easy!

author: jasonkrotine

description.text: A foot for steel tube cantilever-type chairs (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantilever_chair) such as the Breuer chair. The foot snaps over the bottom 1" metal tube. A short stub fits into the hole on the bottom of the chair to keep the foot in place.

Printed with a .4mm layer height and 2 perimeters in ABS.  Make sure to place the stl side-down (not facing up) prior to slicing.  When you slice the stl, the side walls that grip the tube should be solid perimeters only (no cross fill), which will make them flexible enough to expand and snap over the tube.  I found that even though it is an overhang with no support, the stub is short enough that it prints fine.  Your mileage may vary, meaning you may need to clean it up (round off the bottom of any drooping overhang) with a knife or dremel tool.  
If for some reason you need one without the stub, you can easily delete it from the sketchup file and re-export.

comments.text: I'd imagine printing it with the open side up (as in the picture) would remove all overhangs. most printers should be capable of the 45degree angles.
comments.author: Doxin

comments.text: Actually, you don't want to do that, because it's important the curve of the arms are printed with the perimeters.  If you print it facing up, the arms will be done in layers, and therefore not as flexible and more brittle (meaning they may break when you try to snap them on).  I learned this the hard way.
comments.author: Doxin

comments.text: ah good point. hadn't though of that. you could always either go with a pyramid nub so the angles arent too steep, or with a screw. but I suppose this works fine too.
comments.author: cahorton

comments.text:
so the bed is just to kind of keep the bottom layer sticking ?? but all the other layers want to cool off ?
is this for pla only or better for abs ? ABS does have the tendancy to warp quite a bit as it grows ... esp if u have a long part where there is a long time between printing on one end before it gets back to the other ..
comments.author: freNRG

comments.text: PLA doesn't need a heat bed to stick, and the blower fan won't start until after the base layer is printed. ABS and higher temp filaments need a heated bed to prevent the base layer from curling up by cooling to fast, and they don't need cooling fans at all. So in a nutshell, don't use a heated bed for PLA, & don't use a cooling nozzle for ABS. There are exceptions, but that's the gist of it.

description.text:
This Thing includes complete design files in OpenSCAD and instructions for customizing to your own needs. There is a set of stls which can be printed to produce the example shown in the videos. Note that the zip archive provides some files not listed separately. Have a look at video here: http://youtu.be/NP0ElIfxF14
The inspiration for this Thing was Thing 43176 and the first section of video is of my build of Thing 43176 in action. It provides about a 50:1 reduction. In the video, you can see that the output slows the drill down a lot. To build this, I had to reduce the rotor stl 98% with netfabb, then enlarge the bearing mounting ring with a Dremel. Pretty cool result, but three things were lacking. First, it's too big â€“ bigger than the NEMA 14 I wanted to mount it on. Second, the gear ratio is too high. Third, the output shaft is M8; I'd like it to be M5.
Looking for more information, I found Thing 8348 and Thing 19649. While these provided very useful pointers to hypocycloid design info (and the crucial Alex Lait script), there still seemed to be a lack of information on how to actually design a hypocycloid gear reducer. My Thing and the files associated with it are an attempt to explain the process in more detail. It is both an extension of the design and an explanation of how to create a Hypocycloid Gear Reducer. While not quite ready for Customerizer, it should help a lot of people design these devices.
The remainder of the video shows the design this Thing (25:1 reduction) running on a NEMA14 stepper. The motor is running at 5 and 10 revolutions per second. It also shows the same motor without the reducer running at 5 and 10 rps. The final section shows the reducer being reversed.
Credit where credit is due:
The key enabler for the Hypocycloid Gear Reducer is the Python script from Alex Lait ( http://www.zincland.com/hypocycloid/ ). None of this would be possible without it. While I provide a slightly modified version of the script to make it easier to use from the Python IDE in Windows, I have done nothing to improve the calculations in the script in any way. All credit goes to Alex Lait.
Likewise, the detail design of this two cam reduction is the work of JEdren (Thing 43176). All credit for the details goes to him.
All I have added is an OpenSCAD version of the design and the instructions for modifying and customizing the design. I hope you find this useful.

Materials:
Printed parts.
1 - NEMA14 stepper motor. (Shaft on mine was threaded; put a set screw in the input shaft if you need one.)
2 - Bearing 6700ZZ 10x15x4 Shielded Ball Bearing from vxb.com
2 - Bearing 5x10 Shielded 5x10x4 Miniature Ball Bearing from vxb.com
1 â€“ M5x25mm (or the length for your application) hex head bolt. This is the output shaft.
4 â€“ M3x35mm hex socket bolts to mount to a NEMA14 stepper motor
Assembly:
Print one each of all the parts. I print with 0.2mm layer height, 40% infill, infill every other layer, two vertical shells, and three horizontal shells, but I don't think it's critical.
(I found it helpful to use a Dremel with a rotary file to clean up the printed parts. Using this gently can make it easier to fit the bearings and to get the rotor to rotate smoothly.)
Put one of the 10mm bearings onto the input shaft.
Put the lower case over the motor shaft and put the input shaft on the motor shaft. The motor shaft should protrude from the input shaft about 3mm to 5mm.
Put the rotor onto the input shaft and seat the bearing.
Put the other 10mm bearing onto the input shaft and seat into the rotor.
Put one 5mm bearing into the output block. The motor shaft will seat in this.
Put the head of the M5 bolt (output shaft) into the pocket on the output block.
Put the other 5mm bearing into the pocket in the upper case.
Put the output case onto the output shaft and use the M3 bolts to mount the Hypocycloid Gear Reducer to your motor.
Spend the next hour or so fiddling and filing, dissembling and assembling to get everything moving smoothly and easily.
Note that the gearboxes seen running in the videos had no lubrication applied. A little plastic lubricant makes things noticeably smoother.
Use this Thing as the heart of your own cool project, or design a new version (using the instructions I provide) to do just what you want.
Note: To build the exact version I provide, you may want to Scale the cams for the rotor to 99% when you import them to OpenSCAD. I had to do a bit of filing with a Dremel to get smooth motion. Note that scaling on input to OpenSCAD is preferred to scaling with netfabb since all the openings will be unscaled and the correct sizes. The minor downside is you have to generate a new stl for the rotor.
But, I hear you say, I want a different gear ratio, output shaft, or input shaft. Can I modify your design in that way? Yes you can! Following is a summary of the procedure, but I provide all the information you need as a pdf in the zip archive you can download. If you have questions, post them to this forum.
Roll-Ur-Own Overview
Caution: customizing this project is probably not a good first project. I assume you are familiar with Python and OpenSCAD. As the saying goes, batteries not included, some assembly required, and your mileage may vary.
Running the Python script: Use the Python script from Alex Lait to generate the cam and roller profiles used in the OpenSCAD files. The Python script included with the files for this Thing is the latest version of the script from Alex Lait. You can follow the link above to learn a lot more about it. I assume you know how to run Python and use the IDE.
Using LibreCAD: LibreCAD (www.LibreCAD.org) is a very handy 2D drafting program and is perfect for processing the output of the Python script. This processing prepares the cam and roller profiles for further processing by Inkscape. The roller design from the Lait script needs additional work to create a usable profile.
Using Inkscape: The method of processing files for OpenSCAD using Inkscape is well-known (http://repraprip.blogspot.com/2011/05/inkscape-to-openscad-dxf-tutorial.html). The process is followed to ready the cam and roller files for use in OpenSCAD.
The cam and roller profiles can now be imported into OpenSCAD. The profiles are extruded to form the key parts of the design My OpenSCAD file is included as a complete example.

A pdf of detailed instructions for using the python script to create your own dxf profiles is also included. The Instructions page summarizes the process as well.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: It deserves more views! This could be a better alternative to planetary gears in many places: easier to print (less post-processing), more compact and so. How does it  handle wear with time though?
comments.author: MoonCactus

comments.text:
Yeah, I think they have great potential. But they're different and people often avoid different.
Wear? I haven't been using them long enough to be sure, but the contact is all rolling contact, so the wear should be pretty low. Also, a little lithium grease (for plastic - not petroleum based) should work great to keep wear to a minimum.
comments.author: MoonCactus

comments.text:
Awesome set of instructions and intro to these great gears.
What these gears really are is a two stage planetary gear where the sun has been removed and replaced with a planet holder. Due to the planets being linked and the difference in lobes from one set to the other, the output rotation is, well, differential against the first.

title: Pin hinge for 3D printer or other enclosure

description.text:
I created this pin hinge with chamfer's and a beefy pin to increase it's strength. I thought that 3 would be required, but 2 have held up well with no sagging on a 24"x24"x0.177" acrylic door.   
I printed these using ABS on a M2 Makergear.  I fastened them with 10-24 button head screws (this is the size of the hole).  
This won't work for EVERY application, but I was able to use them on both my 3D printer and CNC mill enclosures (white on printer, yellow on CNC).  
Thanks for checking it out!!

comments.text:
Looks real nice. I have a M2 as well and was trying to deceide what I want from an enclosure.
I was thinging side access would be important also venting to the outside. regards
Simon Shabtai Evan
comments.author: Shabtai

comments.text:
I considered building a side access door, but honestly the machine is so light that you just pivot it and get to it's side. The entire enclosure is a 24" cube (~61cm), which is enough room to reach in and change filament, etc.
As for venting, I leave the door cracked 1" or so when printing ABS (110C bed, 240C extruder) and the inside of the enclosure reaches about 35C, which I don't think is too hot. I have the power supply outside, but the computer board is inside.
I thought of all these things (multiple doors and venting, etc.), but decided simple was the right approach. Thanks
comments.author: Shabtai

description.text: THIS THING IS NOT YET FINISHED OR TESTED This is an update to my original omni wheel, this time parameterized in OpenSCAD, which I just learned. I still haven't gotten the O-rings in yet, so I've only been able to test basic fitting of the pieces, not if it actually works as an omni wheel. The project is to remix Arcwave's O-ring based omni wheel with mbbackus's split-ring one. Basically, Arcwave's O-ring idea is great for traction, but the spinners are on plastic axles in a plastic housing, so the rolling friction seems bad. mbbackus's use of a split ring to provide the axle is awesome, but the spinners he uses are washers, so it seems like traction would suffer. Lastly, I don't need them to be as big as either design, and I had 1.5" split rings on hand, so mine are also tiny, and use 8mm ID O-rings instead of 1/2" ones. I haven't gotten the O-rings in yet, so right now they're partly untested. The wheel hub halves and spinners do indeed print and go together, but I haven't confirmed that the spinners will still work well with O-rings, and I haven't been able to test overall functionality. You're welcome to use them, but they might suck.

CUSTOMIZE the following
  • Measure your split ring with a caliper and input its parameters
  • Select O-rings with a size that works with the split ring you selected. Inner diameters under 8mm are not recommended.
  • Jiggle additional settings as desired.

PRINT the following per wheel
  • 2x hub halves*

  • Spinners (quantity selected during customization, default is 10)

  • I've also included an STL option for one full hub, but I'm not sure how you'd get a split ring on it when it's whole.

OBTAIN the following per wheel:
  • (1x) split ring (key ring)
  • A number of rubber O-rings (search on ebay, they're sold in the 100s for tattoo places, since they're used in piercings).
  • Something to attach the two hub halves (screws, glue, etc.)

DO this stuff:
  • After printing, clean any debris from the spinners and slots in the hub.
  • Wrap each spinner with a rubber O-ring.
  • Put the spinners onto the split ring as you would a key.
  • Sandwich two hub halves into the split ring, maneuvering the spinners into the open slots.
  • For any spinners that don't spin freely, take them back off and widen the hole with a round file, drill bit, or you can even strip it wider with a screw.
  • Attach to robot, drive every direction ever.

title: Objet Cleaning Tool / Ear Digger Contour grip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Working with an Objet printer is fantastic, however removing support material from fragile and complex parts can often lead to catastrophe when using the WaterJet station, as such manual support material is often needed however tedious and difficult it may be. To simplify the task we have designed this ear digger contour grip, a simple and comfortable handle for the common metal 1.8mm ear digger. The small spoon shape will enable you to gently and delicately remove support material from even the smallest feature of your part. ** For those unfamiliar with ear diggers (probably everyone outside Asia), ear diggers are little rakes/spoons used to clean your ears; a metal or wood equivalent to a cotton swab. Please exert caution if you actually use this ear digger contour grip to clean your ears. You can learn more about this thing on our blog
http://prototype.asia/blog/2013/04/24/mastering-your-objet-easy-support-material-removal/ It can also be purchased on Shapeways : http://www.shapeways.com/shops/PrototypeAsia

It only allows for 90-deg rotation. It can be reversed depending on which direction is needed.  
I found that it's best to delete the support under the retainer on the base piece (see pic).... it is not needed, but when it printed the support the first time (using a Makergear M2), it was difficult to remove in that location  I use Simplyfy3D and it was easy to remove the suport.  
The length of the bracket is not suitable for all applications, so if you need a different length and cannot modify yourself, let me know as it's a very simple process for me using my Rhino 3D.  
Thanks!!
You may need to rotate the STL file to print properly. The base piece should be printed so that the axle of rotation is on the Z-axis.

remixed_from.author: kresty
remixed_from.title: Smaller 70% Lightsaber Based on ROTJ Artoo Throwing Model - 5 part

title: Lightsaber Launcher Experiment for Astromech Droids

description.text: THIS CAN BE DANGEROUS.  WEAR EYE PROTECTION.  NOT A TOY.

This is a spring loaded device that launches plastic bits.  If those break it could hurt someone.  Don't use if damaged.  Don't use where unprotected people could be hit.
The STL files weren't good, so I've "repaired" them in 3D Builder.  The sketchup files are probably also terrible, but they're near impossible to fix, so if you use those expect to have to repair the resulting STLs.  
Lightsaber Launcher

I built this because I wanted L3-G0 the Lego Artoo to be able to launch a lightsaber similar to the movie scene. Video on his YouTube at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q97qotXkA6k Support my things please :)
I made this 70.7% size lightsaber to go with my full size, working Lego Artoo - http://L3-G0.blogspot.com - Check out L3-G0's YouTube Videos.
THIS IS NOT A TOY

This is a spring loaded demonstration device that could cause injury.  Wear appropriate eye protection when operating and assembling this device.  This is informational only, I am not responsible if you injure yourself with this 3D model or components constructed from it.  
Clamp for Spring Loaded Lightsaber Ejector

Intended for a demonstration ejecting a .707 scale model lightsaber from an Astromech unit.  This launches about 8-10 feet (3m) in the air and toward the rear of my R2 unit.  Depending on the springs, Lightsaber weight, and orientation, your device may operate differently.  Assume it will injure you and use appropriate safety protection.  
Safety Note

Note that the ABS lightsaber or the ejector itself could be damaged by the spring and split into small shards that could potentially cause injury.  Never use this demonstration device when damaged.  It could also impact the Astromech unit if misaligned either breaking into small dangerous pieces, or causing the Astromech to break and fly into bystanders.  
MY LIGHTSABER HAS SPLINTERED ON IMPACT.  If the tip should clip the dome at high speed, a splinter could fly toward someone's eye!!!  
Required Parts

• Lightsaber ejector
  • Lightsaber (.707 scale - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724456)
  • Spring - 23/32" x 3.5" x .041" (18.26mm x 58.9mm x 1.05mm) Hillman Group #224 - Lowes #246630
  • 1/4" (6 to 7mm) Dowel rod 7.5" (190mm) long
  • 3 - #4 screws of appropriate length, &/or fasteners. Metric can be substituted.
  • Servo, 12V Door Lock Type or similar throw/strength.
    • Printing Instructions

You need the inner clamp, outer clamp and a lever arm. Which lever arm depends on how you intend to mount it. This probably requires ABS printing. I printed all of them on standard .2mm layer height, 15% infill, 3 shells with supports, no raft. There are 3 lengths of straight lever arms and a bent arm. I used the nominal straight arm.
Straight arm is intended for a horizontally oriented servo, bent arm for a vertically oriented servo. I think it's best if the inner and outer clamps are oriented with the layers horizontal, along the length of the clamp bits. That way they may slide more freely. Notes on printing the lightsaber

Lightsaber is at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724456 It probably should be printed at about .2mm layer height, 2 shells, and 10% infill. I've printed more shells and more infill, but then it gets heavier. That means it doesn't go as far, but it still has the same momentum and is still just as fragile. At 10% infill & 2 shells it weighs about 38 grams. 38 grams will go about 10 feet high and 6-8 feet or so "behind" my droid. At 15% infill & 3 shells it weighs about 46 grams. 46 grams will travel about 8-9 feet high and not as far away At 25% infill & 3 shells it weighs about 56 grams. 56 grams travels 6-7 feet high and not as far away. Regardless of the weight, the spring imparts pretty much the same amount of energy to the ejected lightsaber (the heavier ones might be in contact with the spring longer so might get a little more energy). So they're going to hit you just as hard. But the heavier ones are more solid. And if a human fumbles it, it seems to go wilder places. Assembly Instructions

See photos on thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:792506 1) Remove supports and clean parts.
2) Slide the Inner Clamp into the Outer Clamp. The arm will snap over the end of the outer clamp
3) Ensure the Inner Clamp slides freely in the Outer Clamp. Slight friction is allowable, but the servo will need to be able to move it.
4) Bend a small 1/8" (3mm) hook in the end of the spring. This is to "grab" the clamp so that the spring doesn't eject with the lightsaber.
5) Press the bent end of the spring into the Outer Clamp. It needs to fit firmly. You may drill a small hole for the bent string to rest in.
6) Insert the dowel in the center of the Outer Clamp from the top. The bottom needs to be flush with the bottom of the hole. You may need to file the inside of the hole, and a metric dowel may need glue to affix it as the hole was designed for a 1/4" dowel (which fits very tightly for me).
7) Use a #4 (or appropriate metric) screws to attach the upper end of the lever arm to the end of the inner clamp.
8) Use another screw to attach the center of the lever arm to the pivot.
9) Use the last screw to attach the end of the servo to the end of the lever arm. Installation

This assembly is designed to mount on my center post with the servo attached to a crossbar that is convenient to my robot.  In this orientation, the two screw holes are mounted to the post on the front/back centerline of the Astromech, and 1.5" to the right (or left) of center.  
The servo needs mounted so it can pull (or push) the lever either horizontally (or vertically) depending on the lever arm and available room.  It's maximum pull should be just past the "open" position of the clamp.  
Programming

I've programmed the microcontroller to require an RC switch to be toggled twice within one second to prevent accidental firing.  With the appropriate signal, it triggers the servo for 0.5 seconds, and then stops automatically. Most microcontrollers will need some sort of external relay board to trigger the servo as the servo can draw > 2A.  
Loading

I'm loading manually:  Ensure the clamp is open, shove lightsaber over the launch rod until the spring is fully compressed, and then close the clamp.  You will need to ensure that the bottom knob is aligned to the clamp's recesses.  
Launching

THIS THING COULD HURT SOMEONE.  Wear eye protection.  Ensure everyone is out of the danger area.  
Stand to the rear and side of the robot.  Ensure the pie panel is open.  Remotely trigger the servo.  Catch the flying object.  
If it fails to launch, toggle the servo a couple more times.  If it still fails to launch carefully manually release and reload the lightsaber.  
Don't stand over it with your face above the spring loaded lightsaber.  Trust me, it's a stupid thing to do.  
Troubleshooting

I haven't had much trouble with it, but ensure that the parts of the inner clamp that the lightsaber slips off of are smooth.  Also that the top of the inner clamp and outer clamp (where the spring shoves them together) are reasonably smooth.  Ensure that the servo is drawing correctly, you can manually trigger it to see if it's "too hard" for your servo.  
Support my things please :)

This was built to go with my full size, working Lego R2-D2 - http://L3-G0.blogspot.com - Check out L3-G0's YouTube Videos. Follow him on twitter @myL3G0 My wife also now has a mouse droid at http://MCK-Y.blogspot.com and check out MCK-Y's YouTube Videos. - Her twitter is @ourMCKY

title: SanDisk Cruzer Blade - The Better Keychain Edition

description.text:
First off, credit where credit is due. Thanks to NilsRoe here on Thingiverse, I was able to create this. This is a housing/casing for the SanDisk Cruzer Blade flashdrive, currently intended to be used on a Keystone (not yet made). However, due to the nature of the 4mm hole at the end of the housing, you should be able to attach it to any keychain. Design changes:
  • Extended tail end to accommodate hole (deliciously centered).
  • Included lid to glue on the other side
  • Smoothed angles on transition of lower to higher interior platform of main housing
    • Changelog:
  • 02.09.2017 8:35am - Posted version just broke, after nearly two years. I'm okay with that. Marking the project as 'finished.'
  • 04.26.2015 6:00pm - By lowering entire base, the drive housing was now too thick to fit into a USB slot. Oversight. Also, pushed rear wall of the bed back 1mm, as the bed did not accommodate my 128GB Blade drive.
  • 04.25.2015 4:45pm - Inner bed of main housing wasn't thick enough. Dropped the bottom of the entire housing by 1mm, should be good to go now. Not yet tested. Uploaded separate files.
  • 04.25.2015 2:00am - As of this posting I have not yet printed this. I will in the morning. This is untested.
    • Made using SketchUp.

The engraving is quite beautiful if lit by an super bright LED.
The Pink Panther was found on:
http://www.dxf-world.de/Web/index.php/en/animals/others/392-paulchen-panther.html?jsn_setwidth=float&jsn_settextsize=big The top and bottom dxf files where created by exporting 2d projections using openscad. Look at the end of the scad file and comment in/out what You need.

Adjust geometry for Your parts (switch, battery holder).
I used 15mm depth in Wood for the acrylic glas, 21mm depth for the switch, 22mm for LED and 21 mm for the battery holder. Acrylic glas can be easily polished by using Xerapol Plastic Polish.
Please do not use the XT variant of acrylic glas, it melts to easy when engraved.
GS or Makrolon should be better. Solder:
Bat+ -- Resistor -- SwitchKontakt1
SwitchKontakt2 -- LED+
LED- -- Bat-

author: omega-xis

description.text:
A coupler that has 2 off vertical constraints (which can be fixed) and 1 off horizontal constraint which can be locked with a knob. The PVC pipes which it couples are 20mm water pipe (~26mm OD). The spacing of the vertical constraints is based on 2 off elbows flush setting the distance. Used in the corelines A2 lightbox.
(http://www.instructables.com/id/A2-overhead-corner-LEDs-lightbox/)

Parts needed:
  • 2 off conduit_single_collar
  • 2 off conduit_cross_brace
  • 1 off conduit_cross_brace_plate
  • knob_M6
  • 1 off M6 Hex Bolt 20mm length
  • 2 off M3 Button Head 12mm screws with nuts
  • 8 off 4G x 9mm self tapper pan head screws
    • Steps:
  • Insert M6 bolt in knob_M6
  • Insert M6 nut in conduit_cross_brace_plate
  • Set 2 off M3 nuts in one of the conduit_cross_brace
  • Fasten conduit_cross_brace_plate to conduit_cross_brace with M3 screws
  • Fasten top and bottom conduit_cross_brace to left and right conduit_single_collar with 4G screws.
  • Insert 20mm water pipes in conduit_single_collars and between conduit_cross_brace_plates

description.text: This is based of the Parametric card organizer for Android Netrunner LCG http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:334172 It is designed to quickly find any faction from the gamebox, there are so many of them. The box holding the victory points is made from this parametric box : Parametric Box with Sliding Lid

I added a text extrusion on the side to writer anything. Here I wrote the name of each faction with a font that would fit the theme. You are free to edit the scad files to use any font you want, just edit the font size to fit your text on the box.  
There is an scad file for single line text and another for 2 lines, so you don't need to heavily edit things.

comments.text: This file format is not supported by Makerbot Print.  I cannot open it with Autodesk Inventor, either.  Any way you could re-post as an .stl file?
comments.author: montypythoner

comments.text: It's an scad file, you're supposed to open it with something like OpenSCAD. It's a parametric file, so an stl would be worthless. Open in OpenSCAD, adjust the parameters to your liking, render, save as an STL.
comments.author: montypythoner

comments.text: Ok, thanks for the tip.  The software I've been using exclusively is Autodesk Inventor, which doesn't recognize scad files and, also, has a hard time with stl files.  I'll try OpenSCAD and, I believe, Autodesk has some other software that's free for educators that might work.  You suggest adjusting the parameters to my liking, but wouldn't there be only a small range that would work with the cards and the box?  Thanks again.

author: ChrisKiwi

description.text: gps stand ,top can used the same.

Calbuco is a stratovolcano located in southern Chile in the Los Lagos Region. This map was constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (almost 2 million polygons). It was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I used to get warping using PLA and it got bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. Now that I have a heated bed, I get much better results.
5%fill density

title: Ticket to Ride Europe / Aventuriers du Rail game organizer

description.text:
Boxes for each player, separate compartment for the 3 stations and the train tokens. These boxes were made so that there's just enough room in them, so I had to make support to place under each box. I've also made covers so that tokens don't damage the game board.  
Not all the covers have the same size, because for some reason the box designers made the top and bottom holes different size.
Covers are included for every colors with the name of the color in both English and French.

comments.text: Works great. Do you have one where the cover doesn't have any text?
comments.author: ZubairHamed

comments.text: For your information: The reason that the rooms on the 'bottom' are smaller is that in the US-version (I will assume that this is the original version of the game) the cards are about half the size and all the train-rooms have the same size. In all other versions of the game (that I have seen) the normal/large cards are used and because of this they had to squeeze the two 'bottom' rooms to make room for the larger card.

title: Prusa i3 3D Phoenix cable chain mod

description.text: Pour remplacer le serre-câbles spiralé par autre chose, j'ai adapté cette chaîne porte-câbles : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:611593 pour la faire tenir sur une 3D Phoenix. Le côté droit est fixé sur le moteur d'extrusion, et le côté gauche est fixé dans l'encoche servant auparavant à faire passer les câbles. J'ai aussi créé un petit guide en arc de cercle pour guider les câbles vers l'arrière de l'imprimante.

CHAIN.STL est un maillon de la chaîne. J'en ai imprimé 27 pour mon imprimante.  
CHAIN-S.STL est le petit clip qui permet de bloquer les câbles dans le maillon.  
CHAIN-Z.STL est le support axe Z à enfoncer dans l'espace qui servait à faire tenir les câbles  
CHAIN-Y.STL est le support axe Y à clipser sur le moteur  
CHAIN-ZSUB.STL est le guide en arc de cercle à fixer en dessous de chain-z.stl pour guider les câbles vers l'arrière de l'imprimante

Super Mutant Master from Fallout 3. According to - http://fallout.wikia.com/wiki/Super_mutant -
Super mutant masters are considered to be the group leaders of the mutant bands which plague the Capital Wasteland. They have more Hit Points than most "common" super mutants. They are discernible by their armor, which appears to consist of what resembles black tubing that wraps around their lower and upper body and something like a fighter pilot helmet. A gas mask is strapped to their left shoulder, possibly acting as a makeshift pauldron. They are generally never alone and are usually accompanied by one or two brutes.

title: Webcam mount for 4mm Y carriage frame

description.text:
This simple webcam support will fit an Y carriage baseplate of 4.2mm or a bit less. I made this for my Logitech HD Pro C920 webcam which has a threaded hole.  
The nice thing about this mount is that you can put it almost anywhere around your bed. There is a bit of vibrations with high speed back and forth movement, but the results are looking great.  
Still looking for ways to improve this object of course.
Print on the side with support. Mount webcam, insert it somewhere on your printer bed, have fun.

comments.text: Having used it for a while, I would advise against using PLA to print this part. Being that close to the bed make the part soft in the long run, mine started to be considerably bent at the end parts.

author: BorisLandoni

title: Cardbox - A customizable box holder for cards or tiles

description.text:
I designed this to be as simple as possible. I wanted something that wouldn't use a lot of filament and would also serve as dispenser when the lid is removed. I use it for tiles, for cards, but really this can be used for anything stackable you can think of.  
I printed at least dozen of these, the common issue I have is the lid is not holding everything tight enough when the tolerance is at 2. When it is tighter, it holds perfectly. I'll keep this thing as work in progress for the time being, I need to think of a better way to hold the lid and box together.
Use the customizer to make one that perfectly fits your cards. You can also choose to make a support so that it sits tight in your game box.

comments.text:
Any chance you can list some standard sizes for the config of this file? the ones I would be interested in if you have them easily accessible are:
1) Standard cards
2) Escape Tiles

author: Milogom

description.text:
These are token holders for Dungeon Fighter as well as the first 3 expansions. The 4th expansion is coming soon, so I'll have to see what has to be added.  
The blue box is holding the meeple, main dices, as well as other tokens. The top cover is holding all the special tokens, so they're easy to find. The big green box is a dispenser for the buyable dices, the money and the black tokens. Tokens are reloaded from the top, when the fall on the bottom, there is a slight curve that pushes the tokens forward 1-2mm for easy retrieval.  
I'll keep this thing as work in progress while waiting for the final expansion of the game.
NOTE : If you liked the font I used in the SCAD file, it is called "Headline HPLHS".

remixed_from.title: Cardbox - A customizable box holder for cards or tiles

description.text:
So many little tokens in this game, I had to do something. First I printed a Cardbox for the cards, and then I made little tokens to glue the boats on them. At first I wanted to print actual little boats, but the game box is quite small so they wouldn't fit.  
The token box fits all the swords tokens, the single swords on each sides, and the 5 swords in the middle. In the back are all the dices and card support. The cover feature a glueable logo that serves as support and makes the box sit tight in the box.
Glue piratesTitle in the middle of piratesCouvercle as featured in the pictures if you want the tokens to stay in place when the box is closed.

remixed_from.author: Nicofr57
remixed_from.title: Cardbox - A customizable box holder for cards or tiles

description.text:
So much things in this game, I didn't even know where to start. Of course like my other releases, it features my Cardbox creation.  
The tile holder is pretty simple and holds them all together. The meeples and dices are held together by the cover. All the meeples are grouped (2*5 for players, 4, 3, 2 and 1 for additionnal actions, the dog, Vendredi and something else I forgot about).  
Next up is the special tokens box, not many of them, but they needed to have a box.  
The box with the treasure pile and the 3 "?" big tokens was the hardest to make. Well, the cover was. Anyway, it also holds damage and determination tokens.  
With that many cubes it was hard to find a great solution, but I think this one works quite nicely. A little support sits under the cube boxes so that there is enough tilt for the cubes to slide down. And here it is, a nice little cube dispenser.

robinsonDistriCube and robinsonDistriPetitCube needs to be glued together as shown in the pictures. As this is a little bit hard to print correctly because of too much bridging, I thought spliting the part in 2 would help.

There are 3 separate cover so it is not confusing when you play with or without expansions.  
Of course when playing with expansions, you are supposed to remove all the tiles, mix them together and put them back. Keeping expansions 1 and 2 in the last rows are for storage or playing without them.  
I really liked making this design and am working on making it parametric so that I can use it in all tile based games (Carcassonne, ...)

I think that the weakness of the stock landing skids is rather annoying.
So I preferred a much more robust solution.

Diagonal mesh bracelet I designed in openSCAD. Designed to print without support, though you may need to print with a brim.  
Prints great at 0.2mm layer height.  
Once printed, the opening in the band may need a quick sanding to make sure it isn't scratchy.

This puzzle is similar to the rubik's cube and is currently massed produced and can be purchased from the producer, Meffert's. However I wanted to design a smaller, flat faced version. It also has a different mechanism than the massed produced version. It should work perfectly in theory, though finding the right size screw might take some work. I could always add pins that you could just glue in place if anyone wants. I also split two of the parts in half because of overhang problems. This way it should be able to be printed without support material, and then the two halves would have to be glued together.
Unfortunately I don't really know how to orient the pieces, so hopefully you guys can do that yourselves.
With that being said I hope someone attempts to make this, and I am sorry ahead of time if it doesn't work
Edit 1) 4/21/11: Changed the instructions to make it more clear.

Print all of the parts included in the part list first. on both the edge and the corner the part is split into two pieces to account for overhang. You must first glue these pieces together. The edge pieces should be interchangeable, but the corner pieces need to be placed so they make a nice uniform triangular-like prism. 
Finally, find a screw that fits through the center pieces freely, but can be screwed securely into the core file into the 4 designated holes. Once all of the Centers are in place it is a matter of placing the edges in between two centers and the corners in between three edges. It is very similar to assembling a Rubik's cube, which I recommend searching for a video of if you are having difficulty. 
It isn't really a puzzle without color on it, but it could still be fun to play with.

comments.author: rockergeek101

comments.text:
The original design is very small. For first print, I have scaled to 200%, this is big. 150% will be a good number. Instead of screws, take M3 rods, drill and glue into the center sphere. Then you will have a sphere with legs. ABS, acetone vaporized will be a good idea, sphere printed with 70% infill. Maybe a steel washer between sphere and 'center' part for better rotation. From outside to the center part, also a steel washer. If you like, a gummy-"washer" cutted from a bicycle inner tube, then a second washer and a self-locking nut. Print in ABS, acetone vaporized. If not, PLA will work. After painting the color marks, add some grease to the moving surfaces.
Look up, you will need 4 corner parts and 4 of them flipped (mirrored). Edge parts you will need 12, doesn't matter which side.

Inspired by Speedy777's Pump Drill (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:731086, which was inspired by Performance 3D's drill), this slightly beefier version features an adjustable chuck that can handle bits from 5mm (3/16") down to 1.5mm (1/16"). The end of the bit seats in the conical shaped chuck cavity, and the flexy fingers at the tip grab further up the shank. You get 2 full rotations per stroke for fast drilling. It also works as a pin vise for holding needle files.

Update: I've uploaded a new version of end_nub.STL which should fit better.  
All parts were printed in PLA with 3 perimeters and 30% infill.  The drill body was printed on end with 0.2mm layers - you may need a brim.  The slider, chuck and end nub were printed with 0.16mm layers.  The difference in layer height keeps the layer-line ridges from lining up with those on the drill body and makes for smoother operation.  Note that the chuck threads may need a little cleaning up with a triangular file.  
To assemble, first push the slider onto the body.  Next, put a little dab of grease on the end nub pin and click it onto the end of the drill body.  It should spin freely.  Finally, put a little bit of grease on the chuck threads and also on the outside of the tips of the flexy fingers and then screw on the chuck.  
To use, insert your bit (1.5 to 5mm) into the chuck until the end of the bit hits the bottom of the conical chuck cavity.  Then tighten the chuck just enough so you can't rotate the bit with your fingers.  Do not over-tighten - the flexy fingers will break!  This drill works best with very light downward pressure and a little patience.  (Tip: to drill larger holes, start by drilling a smaller pilot hole.)

comments.text: Great design! It took a bit of trial-and-error but I got a good print from my M3D Pro for this. The main body I printed at 0.98x, the chuck at x1, the end-pin at x1 (and sanded it a lot...) and the slider at 1.04x on the X/Y axes and x0.98 on the Z to match the body (oddly the chuck works great, despite the Z axis mismatch). With a bit of lubrication, it's pretty easy to use. I tried 1.02x first for the slider and it was just a bit too tight, 1.04 seems about right.

description.text:
The makerbot finally printed me some glasses! I decided to start out with some nice thick frames inspired primarily by Cory Doctorow and Bre Pettis, though I have plans for a lot more styles and shapes. As for practicality...
I honestly wasn't expecting these to be comfortable but they actually are. They're really light and after a while I forget I'm even wearing them. I can even wear them over my normal glasses.
PLUS major geek bonus points for wearing GLASSES YOU PRINTED YOURSELF.

I subdivided the glasses into 7 parts (there's a picture below with labels on all the parts). All you need to do is print one of each. Glue a couple together and stick part of a paper clip through the hinges.
They fit my face pretty much perfectly. Let me know if people need the back pieces longer/shorter and that can definitely be done easily.

description.text: Sometime probably in the 1400's it probably took some poor dudes a lifetime to learn how to mine the marble, transport it to Venice, and painstakingly chisel out this Lion statue. Fast forward to 2011 and some guy with an iPhone can visit Venice on vacation, take a few pictures, upload it to the internet and within minutes it can be recreated in plastic miniature on my desktop on the other side of the planet! I cleaned up this awesome scan, resized it, and made it into a solid. You'll need to turn on support! Update: I uploaded a new version that properly sets his feet on the platform. If you tried printing it and it started too high, re-download the new stl.

Printing Tips: Using Skeinforge 35, turn on raft, set support to exterior only. Under raft:
Support Minimum Angle (degrees): 46.0
Support Flow Rate over Operating Flow Rate (ratio): 1.5
Support Gap over Perimeter Extrusion Width (ratio): 1.0
Raft Additional Margin over Length (%): 1.2
Raft Margin (mm): 3.0
Interface Infill Density (ratio): 0.5 To prevent it from doing tons of bridge layers that result in almost 100% infill, go into Carve and turn off Infill in Direction of Bridges! Also I used 1 extra shell and infill at 0.1

I have looked around and couldn't find a tray with an odd number of compartments.  So, I made one.  I needed an odd number to sort bullets by weight.  Center is 0, to the right is +.1 and +.2 grains and to the left -.1 and -.2 grains.  
I have included a 5 bin tray as well as a single bin you can print any number of to suit your needs.  While I designed them for my reloading bench, they could just as easily be used to sort anything from screws to beads.  
The interior front and back bottom corners are beveled so its easy to scoop items out of the tray.

author: Fluffy20

title: Bullet Centering Plate for Innovative Technologies OAL Gauge

description.text:
This is a pretty specific thing.  If you happen to own an Innovative Technologies OAL gauge from Larry Willis, well, this thing is for you :)  
It will center the case head on the plate in the same place every time making OAL and headspace measurements more repeatable and accurate.  It is not caliber specific and should work with just about any case.  Its pictured with a 300 Winchester Magnum (belted) round so I think it will work on just about any round of any diameter.  
You will need one 3mm heat set insert and one 3mm cap screw to lock it in place.

author: Wolfie

title: R.A.T.5 pinky board with 5 degree tilt

description.text: the original (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:56545) pinky board didn't fit my rat5 properly because the entire board seemed tilted roughly 5 degrees. quick fix and it fits perfectly.
